Back at the tour coach, the successful team get their well-deserved praise.
As far as they're concerned, a dog's life is the only life,
as long as they've someone to share it with.
North of France Joseph Township, about a mile along the main highway,
there's an interesting new growth in the bush,
a development that means a good deal to the people of the West Coast. On a site of seven acres a modern tourist hotel is now being built,
in a part of New Zealand long famous for its natural beauty of mountain and bush
and the friendliness of its people.
The building of the new hotel holds a special interest for members of the Graham family,
whose ownership and management of the Franz Joseph Hotel for nearly half a century
established a great tradition of service and hospitality for tourists and travelers.
Here in about six months' time, visitors will wine and dine in luxury.
Only a few yards away is the river terrace where at the turn of the century,
Mr. William Batson built an accommodation house for local gold miners and tourists.
In the early 1900s, the heyday of the Hanson cab,
travelled beyond the city streets was something of an adventure.
A journey from Christchurch to the Westland glaciers meant seven days or more in a hard sprung coach,
with all the excitements of river crossings and the pitfalls of half-formed mountain roads.
But to the Edwardians, typified by Prime Minister Seddon's party climbing the glacier,
the rewards of enterprise were always high enough to justify the hazards.
And in 1911, as more tourists came under the spell of Westlands Mountains,
the accommodation house was bought and extended by two brothers from Ocorito,
James and Alex Graham.
Soon the hotel was flourishing at the center of a growing township.
And in summer 1911, the arrival of the first motor car, 12 hours and nine punctures from Hokka
Heralded the tourist traffic that was to bring fame and prosperity to Franz Joseph and the glaciers in the years ahead.
By the 1920s, the Franz Joseph Hotel was firmly established as one of New Zealand's
great hotels by the Graham family partnership. This tradition of West Coast hospitality was maintained
when the hotel was bought by the government in 1948. Six years later, fire destroyed everything
but a chimney and outbuildings. A heavy loss to the Franz Joseph community.
But now, as in the past, the township offers a coast welcome to visitors,
and parties of tourists are guided on the white ice of the glacier every day.
The girl from Nelson and the girl from Britain find the glacier trip just as fascinating as their parents did in the 1930s.
Though since then the France has receded, in common with all the world's temperate zone glaciers.
Another attraction for tourists is the cool, unspoiled beauty of Westlands native bush.
Around the glacier and township of Franz Joseph, bush walks are made all the more interesting
with the help of a national park ranger, to the nesting place at Ocorito.
But nothing interrupts the job in hand for long. Work must go on six days a week in a race against time.
The aims to have
the hotel ready for guests before traffic begins to flow along the new scenic highway
through southwestern to Otago in 1965.
Westland raw materials and westland skills are all employed here on a venture that will benefit the whole of the South Island.
And New Zealand's growing tourist industry will gain a valuable asset
when there's once more a first class hotel in the France Joseph Bush
between the Southern Alps and the Tasman Sea. The
